column3: We haven't historically done this, generally I use the tools and process of master no matter what is on the specific branch. But if it helps you, I don't mind.\n(it does raise the question, how far back do you want to go?)

github-merge should be part of a separate repository, since it is not tied to the release process. I think we keep it here to expose it to more review.\n\nAlso, you might want to consider using an out-of-tree github-merge script, as you might have accidentally checked out a branch or pull request that shipped you a modified (potentially malicious) github-merge script.
So tend to NACK, it should either be left untouched or removed
I'll just move to using an out-of-tree script.
